title: How many vacancies will arise on the U.S. Supreme Court in 2021?
preds: I think if any of them were going to retire it would be Stephen Breyer, and none of them seem old enough to be likely to have any serious sudden health issues. But even Breyer would probably wait until after 2024 as he wouldn’t want to risk not getting a new nomination through before the midterms when the Republicans control either the house or the senate.
At this point, it would be quite irrational for a Justice to just leave in the next 6 days in the middle of Christmas week and in the middle of the current session.
Nearly all of my forecasts on this question were almost exclusively limited to biological risk of mortality.
And with 21 days left, flipping over the last percentage point.

if I'm doing the math right, Breyer by the actuarial tables roughly a 1% risk of death in the rest of the year, while everybody else would push that up. However, all the Justices are apparently in good enough health to do their jobs, which then pushes the odds down. All other possibilities (retirement, terrorist attack, whatever) are small enough to just be noise.
The new term has started.  No justice has ever retired in October, November or December.   All the current justices seem heathy enough to last until January 1st.
Update of -1% to 1 vacancy for passage of time.
Baring a sudden death, this question is over.
With the new session of the Supreme Court opening today, the odds are strongly against a retirement not forced by a health issue.

Just sliding a couple points back up after Kavanaugh Covid news (1).  I think he's going to be fine, but US Conservatives have developed some what of a reputation of being more relaxed regarding precautions.  1. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/01/supreme-court-justice-brett-kavanaugh-tests-positive-for-covid-days-before-new-term-begins.html

With only a few months to go and the judges (not least the two eldest) being in apparent good health and Stephen Breyer saying he's not looking at retirement right now*, it seems unlikely but not impossible. *https://www.newsweek.com/justice-stephen-breyer-83-responds-liberal-activists-pressing-his-retirement-1630594
Slight decrease due to the Alito allegations.

I think there's almost zero chance Breyer will leave before the end of the year. The only risk I see is the risk of death, which is probably about 3% to 4% for the remainder of the year.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1295587
Barring a sudden death, moving to zero.
Just tracking the crowd because I don't have a strong view on this right now. Breyer still seems intent on making a statement by not retiring yet last I checked.
One down 5% for passage of time.

New Texas abortion laws [1] (something Breyer appears to have some degree of investment in from previous decisions [2]) and the Mississippi Rowe v Wade challenge coming up in this term [3] and due to resolve in summer 2022 seem likely to be a major factor in Breyer's retirement decision.  To bow out now and hand over to younger blood would feel like giving in to a personal defeat and Breyer seems to be a proud person with an interest in his legacy on the SC. My previous premise that Dems would ideally not like an SC seat to be an animating factor for Republicans during the 2022 terms has likely been drowned out by the other, more noisy, angles both sides seem to be taking.  So Breyer's retirement after the Mississippi challenge (after this session ends in summer 22) now seems far more likely and less politically impactful than I'd previously surmised. Breyer will probably make this his legacy decision (or dissent) and then step down after this SC term to allow the Biden team the room to smoothly swap in another moderate / Liberal justice a few months before the 2022 mid terms (holding Liberal seats on the SC whilst they can and neatly taking the SC seat off the ballot for November 22 in the same moment). Risky, in case the Reps find a way to stall beyond the mid terms (pressure or promises to one of the more conservative Dems: Manchin or Sinema?) and/or if the numbers in the Senate change in this time, but Breyer seems determined to leave something behind he can be proud of and does not appear to be swayed by the noisy voices warning of a repeat of the RBG debacle. All other routes to a surprise vacancy remain theoretically open but base rated in the "very unlikely" / "extraordinary event" zone.  Dropping to align with the crowd now. [1]  https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-58406496
[2]  https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/supreme-court/supreme-court-s-breyer-mentioning-abortion-case-warns-about-overturning-n1005066
[3] https://www.reuters.com/world/us/mississippi-asks-us-supreme-court-overturn-abortion-rights-landmark-2021-07-22/
It's only a month until the new term begins: https://www.supremecourt.gov/about/procedures.aspx With the Senate in  recess, I don't think there will be any voluntary retirements this year
No one is leaving by choice this year (death always a possibility) only chance of vacancies come is somehow the court is expanded.
1 up 5%, @cdob63 can't be wrong all the time. ;-)
Mr. Justice Breyer seems to be wavering even more than usual.
Per prior rational, while adding small possibility of expansion to the Court (3+ seats).

Crunching the actuarial numbers:
https://www.thegreenpapers.com/Hx/SupremeCourt.html
https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
Adjust for 4 months of the year remaining.  = 6.2%;  (deduct 1% for possibility of another vacancy)
Could make minor adjustments for Covid, better average healthcare for these Justices, no known serious medical conditions (ie. cancer)
Seems unlikely Breyer is retiring, especially after the summer session is mostly complete.  Vacancy would seem to mean we would retire prior to the end of the year (ie. not just announcing retirement).
Barring a death on the Court, this is not happening.
One down 10% for passage of time.

Rolling down with time and the reduced likelihood of Breyer departing in the autumn and winter season (not impossible but less likely given some decisions coming up). Historical analysis of trends for base rate didn't really help on this one: provided below in case it proves useful to someone. "Thus, other things equal, retirement odds increase by 168% (= e0.9850 – 1) when the incumbent president is from the same political party as the president who nominated the justice and the presidential administration is in its first or second year (compared with the odds when the incumbent president is from a different political party and a presidential administration is in the third or fourth year of its four-year term)." https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3000028/

It's pretty clear that Justice Breyer isn't going to retire this year. Then the only question would be deaths. 
Risks of mortality in the absence of retirement are probably about 7% to 8% for July through Dec. I'm decreasing that to 6% for now through Dec. Details here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1295587

https://www.wsj.com/articles/supreme-court-stephen-breyer-retirement-politicization-blumenthal-cnn-11626989813 Anthony Kennedy was able to be pressured into retiring, but it's just not working with Breyer.

Beyer is not going anywhere . . . https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/15/politics/stephen-breyer-retirement-plans/index.html . . . Pretty much confirmed it in this CNN interview.  So, barring a surprise, it looks like no vacancies will occur this year.
One down 20% for passage of time.
Risks of mortality in the absence of retirement should be considered and are probably about 7% to 8%. Details here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1295587

A vacancy is actually a stronger requirement than an announcement of retirement, didn't consider this earlier.  Possibility of Breyer announcement prior to midterms but Senate should remain at least 50 democrats even after midterms (https://www.270towin.com/2022-senate-election/).  I'll take my P(Breyer retirement) at about 2% as he'd sooner announce retirement than actually see it through this year and has given every indication of the opposite including recently hiring 4 new clerks.  P(death resulting in vacancy) is about 2.6% according to a 2010 study (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3000028/).  Round up to 5%.

The Breyer probability of retirement keeps sinking, the chance of COVID taking a Justice out is now minimal . . . Breyer (or less likely another justice) still could not wake up one morning, of course.
p(dying within year) drops as year progresses, as does p(expansion within year)

From https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/01/politics/breyer-retirement-watch-supreme-court-end-of-term/index.html:
"After the Supreme Court issued its final two opinions of this term on Thursday, all eyes turned to Justice Stephen Breyer, the court's senior liberal who is facing intense calls to retire so Democrats can install a replacement this summer."
"Nothing Breyer has previously said has indicated that he is ready to make a significant announcement. He has also declined to talk about his retirement prospects, and his vision about keeping judges above politics, expressed in a Harvard lecture in April, will be published in a book this September."
"Democrats had initially tiptoed around the issue, but its liberal wing recently became more forthright about its worries, with two progressive lawmakers -- New York Reps. Mondaire Jones and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez -- publicly signaling in recent weeks that they want Breyer to step down." Overall, it seems fairly unlikely but not impossible that he'll retire.

(no change, for now) The Veep is getting some bad press, similar to some reporting when she was campaigning for the top position. If her image becomes even slightly tarnished (Sen Klobuchar interesting comparison class), will that hurt D prospects? in 2022? If there is a sense the GOP is close to re-taking the Senate, there will be some hard choices for one justice.

Whilst Breyer has given no statements or overt signs that he will either voluntarily or unwillingly give in to the pressure for him to retire the conditions of the moment are undeniable and undisputed.  The RBG episode will not be forgotten or ignored easily by the remaining 3 liberal justices on the SC (whatever their moral, ethical and professional views on politically driven decisions like early retirement) and the impactful SC decision, split on political ideology grounds on voting rights (and the fairly egregious doors it has opened for worsening democratic conditions in democracy's backyard), will only add to this pressure within the shrinking liberal community of the SC. Should Breyer Retire?  Morally, ethically, professionally and constitutionally: probably not. But he, and his wider advisory circle, cannot fail to realise the sad reality that they do not move in an ethical, moral, professionally focused or constitutionally bounded environment at this time.  The hard deck of actions that the "other side" WILL take (without much or any uncertainty in that forecast) if the opportunity is given them, and the fragility of the current situation, is a hard deck of fact and certainty, and that WILL be part of their calculations (whether or not they are happy about that). In my mind (and for this forecast) these are more empirically reliable factors for forecasting against than the wishes and desires of one man (and any statements he might wish to make on the subject).  Breyer's wish to remain should be factored in, but ultimately it seems he is a moral man trying to do the right thing. Against this foundational principle, I don't think there is much argument about "what the right thing to do is", and he will at his age be wondering about his legacy: on one path, as a man willing to make a noble personal sacrifice for "the greater good" and on the other a naïve and selfish fool who handed an egregious and morally bankrupt political movement an even greater stranglehold on the country's governance. https://edition.cnn.com/2021/07/01/politics/breyer-retirement-watch-supreme-court-end-of-term/index.html

Pressure is mounting on Justice Breyer to retire. Also, biological risks should be considered:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1295587
Maintaining 5% in case of a surprise (probably a death), but none of them (including Breyer) making any indications on the possibility of leaving the court this year.
Updating forecast due to passage of time.
One down 20% for passage of time.
I should include a non-zero probability that 2 may pass away.

I'll look at this from the biological standpoint first. I'm not aware of any significant health issues for any of the justices, but there could always be some. And surprises happen, of course.  The estimates below are based on 1/2 year death probabilities for average males and females in the US. However, Supreme Court justices are not average men and women and will statistically have higher life expectancies based on their incomes. I have rounded their ages to the nearest year (which, I'm sure, would drive an actuary crazy).
https://www.thegreenpapers.com/Hx/SupremeCourt.html
https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
name, rounded age, probability of death
Clarence Thomas, 73, 1.5%
Stephen Breyer, 83, 4.0%
John Roberts, 66, 0.9%
Samuel Alito, Jr., 71, 1.2%
Sonia Sotomayor, 67, 0.6%
Elena Kagan, 61, 0.4%
Neil Gorsuch, 54, 0.4%
Brett Kavanaugh, 56, 0.4%
Amy Coney Barrett, 49, 0.1%
P(at least one dies) = 1 - P(none dies) = 1 - (0.985*0.960*0.991*0.988*0.994*0.996*0.996*0.996*0.999) = 0.092 => 9.2% (plus or minus some approximation and rounding errors). Again, because these are not average males and females, their individual risks of mortality are likely lower, and hence the overall risk of mortality is likely lower, perhaps around 7%-8%. A number in this range is the minimum risk that should be assigned to this question. The next question is whether any would retire. Breyer is the only real candidate, and he seems very reluctant to do so. If he does, I'd think he'd wait until the last minute, i.e., several months before the midterm elections, not in 2021.

"Nothing Breyer has said publicly suggests the 27-year veteran is ready to leave the work of the court just yet."
"He seems in vigorous health, unlike some retirees in recent years or the late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg"
"Breyer also has a special interest in cases the justices are scheduled to hear next session"
"Breyer would be reluctant to succumb to politically driven pleas" https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/16/politics/stephen-breyer-supreme-court/index.html

-6 on 1 as it's now mid-June and that was my previous time estimate for when I'd start dropping if no announcement from Breyer. I'll probably come down 10 a week from here. The last four retirement announcements were as follows: O'Connor - July 1, 2005
Souter - May 1, 2009
Stevens - April 9, 2010
Kennedy - June 27, 2018
Passage of time. Democratic activists might want Breyer to quit, but they have no influence to exert on him.

Time passage adjusts probabilities a little, but (for now) I stand by the previous premise that the Dems will be feeling the existential concern over a mortality on the Court or in the fragile Senate majority that could leave the door open for an even more conservative SC (see RBG) and that, if Breyer were to leave in 2022, the Dems would be handing the Republicans a voter animating issue ("save the SC!!") at a time when their own voters are facing aggressive suppression and the mid term results could define a lot of the future for the US. As such, any issue could be a tipping point concern and after the RBG fiasco I'd hope that Democrats want to operate with slightly more political savvy than has perhaps been on display previously.
Shaved a bit for passage of time, since nobody's died.
(no change) It would be interesting to have over 80 forecasters' views. My point such as it is, is when one reaches a certain point, things may seem different than random predictions.
Less likely than it was if Breyer won't retire
Breyer is going on a media tour and writing a book about, in large part, partisanship's negative effects on the judiciary.
Breyer is not going anywhere this year.  However, need to account for sudden situations and surprises.

Over correcting on zero to make up for my increasingly unlikely earlier view that Breyer will retire this year.  He has hired a full slate of law clerks for the 2021-2022 court session, suggesting he will be around for at least one more term.[1] [1] https://davidlat.substack.com/p/confession-of-error-justice-breyer

Very outside chance a retirement is forced on a more liberal leaning justice. Most of the Justices are currently on the younger side and/or reported to be in relatively good health for someone of their age.
Scuttlebutt is that Dems are pushing for Meyer to step down before the mid-term...a macabre conversation to be sure, but folks wanna get their judge in place! I'm upping my odds for "1" just a tad.
Pandemic as a wildcard is simmering down. Time decay. Any justice could decide to wait until next year or never if they wanted.
Decided that this may be a hair more likely than not, at least until all the SCOTUS opinions are announced and we see if Breyer does retire. I'll drop significantly if there's no news by mid June.
Will weight 0 more if no news after say June 30.

Its hard to get too bearish on this but the tea leaves say Breyer is mostly likely out next year. That would give his former clerk more time on a federal bench before replacing him. It also tracks with his hiring of 4 law clerks.

If Breyer is going to retire we should know in the next couple months, Souter announced in May 2009 and Kennedy in June 2018. Opinions are typically done being released around then so that explains why it's usually late spring. Maintaining for now but I'll revise downward significantly in early summer if no announcement happens.

Biden creates a commision to consider overhauling the supreme court. (1) Decreases the change of no change a little but its still a low way from adding seats in 2021. 1:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/04/13/bidens-considering-reforming-supreme-court-thats-happened-during-every-crisis-us-democracy/

I have been trying to take a deep look at Justice Stephen Breyer, who is 82.  He is the most likely to resign this year to avoid an election year (grant it mid-term elections) RBG situation and ensure that a liberal is appointed in his place.  The major question is, how is his health?  I cannot find anything regarding his health.  Reviewing his caseload, it appears to be pretty steady and he has hired a full slate of law clerks for the next term, which suggests that he plans to be around for the remainder of the year.  However, there is significant pressure from Democrats and progressives for Breyer to step down out of fear of loosing the Senate in the mid-terms, which history supports is very possible.  At this time, I have no reason to believe that Breyer will step down this year.  The next oldest justices are Thomas (72) and Alito (71).  I do not see either one of them going anywhere anytime soon, especially under a Democratic Administration, with the exception of suddenly passing away.  The rumors of Justice Sotomayor having some underlining health condition that might result in her stepping down has never been supported by any evidence and appears to have just been a Trump Administration rumor.  For now, I am maintaining my forecast, but will be following Breyer involvement in court activities over the next month, mainly how many opinions he pens.

Sometimes things go sideways then they straight then they sideways again. Justice Robert’s resided over President Trumps impeachment.  Side note: the Russia Mueller probe is still ongoing as well as all the spin off investigations. This website was used as evidence to support the Russia Mueller probe. This website is a spin off of IARPA research sponsored by the Washington Post owned by Jeff Bezos. 

There are obstruction of justice complaints with the FBI. An IG complaint with the CIA.  The FBI and other law enforcement organizations are keeping everyone under investigation until world war 3 starts. Most likely the intelligence community supported.  This is one of the biggest scandals in American history. And people are afraid to talk about and when they do they end up in jail for crimes that were never committed. Like me. I spent time in jail for filing the IG complaint and filing an obstruction complaint with the FBI.  WW3 I think starts fairly soon because my case in court is almost over I think.  On the other hand maybe Justice Robert’s will resign the FBI director will resign the CIA will be replaced and the United States will get criminal justice reform. And President Bidon will get to pick a new Supreme Court justice.

Breyer has not made indications of his retirement despite calls for him to retire, and he seems in relatively good health. Given that other legislative items are already on the docket for Biden in the Senate (infrastructure, cabinet appointments, etc.) it seems unlikely that the administration would push Breyer to retire given that would scuttle any other legislative actions for the next 2-3 months. The administration will ask Breyer to retire, but probably in 2022.
Breyer just hired a full slate of clerks for the Supreme Court term beginning in October. Usually that indicates plans to serve the term rather than retire.

https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/09/president-biden-to-sign-executive-order-creating-the-presidential-commission-on-the-supreme-court-of-the-united-states/
So that's step one.
Not sure what to make of this but "The Executive Order directs that the Commission complete its report within 180 days of its first public meeting. " makes me somewhat more skeptical that new vacancies would appear before the end of this year.
Breyer's comments suggest he's about done.

With the news of Biden's commission to explore expanding the court, I see Breyer's chances of retiring this year even less likely. Why would he send out a rare statement about keeping the court non-political and then retire the same year he said such a thing? He knows stepping down this year would appear to be political. That is my assumption. The other Justices are more likely to step down, in my judgement.

Breyer just stated this which I would take as hypocritical if he steps down this year. Not stepping down this year would be consistent with the words he is preaching. https://twitter.com/ABC/status/1380038279677014024 However, one or two Justices have health conditions and one other Justice has been on the court for three decades and could face a health issue. There is also a new threat these days of a lone wolf attacker targeting government leaders' homes (the Harris, Biden scares for example).
Passage of time from original forecast.
Went all out with proper time updating instead of naive 75%. It barely makes a difference.

Going frequentist on this because I think if we see any strategic retirements it'll be next year. In post war years, 30% chance a single justice is replaced and 7.5% chance that two are, adjusted because we are a quarter into the year now. Unless the court comes down with a truly egregious decision, we aren't going to hear anymore talk of court packing.

Nominating Ketanji Brown Jackson to the DC court of appeals takes away the main contender for a Supreme Court nomination, and likely signals that Breyer doesn't intend to step down for at least the next year while Jackson gains experience. I doubt it's Biden's way of locking away someone Breyer doesn't like so he could retire knowing his replacement would be more aligned with him, considering Jackson clerked for him. Breyer is pretty clear about staying out of politics, saying "the more the political fray is hot and intense, the more we stay out of it." Retiring with such a clear (or perceivable) political motive would be out of character, but maybe a situation like this is when you break that character, I don't know. The main probability for 1 seat opening is health issues for him or a change of heart when the session ends in June.
Edging up on the chance of a retirement, purely because of the volume of calls for retirement I see. I honestly don't think he will retire though, so this is a peer pressure inspired change.
After this summer, if there is no retirement, I will adjust upward that no Justice will retire.

Dropping down a little purely due to the passage of time and no retirement yet.  If it is to happen it will likely be a flash announcement and Dems will want to be sure that Manchin and co are on side with a replacement.

Tuning back toward zero. My forecast is currently about 
* 12% chance of one death, 
* 10% chance of a Breyer retirement, 
* 2% chance of two deaths
* 1% chance of a Breyer retirement AND another justice dying. I've given a less than one percent cumulative probability of court packing, impeachment, or other retirements.

Assumes exponential distribution of vacancies per year with Poisson arrival rate.  Previous forecasts tuned lambda based on the average age across the entire court (using vacancy data beginning in 1980).  I discovered that the sum of the age of the two oldest justices was much more correlated with vacancy arrivals, so I'm switching to that.
Maybe dramatic, but I expect if a vacancy arises, it will be because Kavanaugh has been impeached, pending an investigation by the DOJ at the request of Senator Whitehouse.

3 months into 2021 and no vacancies yet.  The fact that the job is a lifetime job seems to have some kind of mental effect of blocking thought of stepping down, which is a bit alarming in a group of people who are supported to be able to make judgments based on a set of rules.  There is nothing stopping retirement, yet they do not.  
Given ages there is only really one possible retirement.  Of course health might get in the way of others, but is unlikely.

Just a neglible tweak toward 0 after reading that even liberal advocacy groups are not pushing for his retirement. They in the past tried to advocate for Justice Kennedy not to retire during Trump's term. Maybe it was due to loss aversion.
Even if Breyer is in perfect health for an 82yo, the fate of his longtime colleague's seat must be weighing heavily on his thinking.

Close to consensus but not as adamant that Breyer will seek to retire. He likes to preach that the Supreme Court has to be respected as an independent institution in America and I think if he decides to retire on a politically advantageous year for the "Liberals" then that would delegitimize the reputation of the court. He may try to serve as long as he can, which could mean well into his 90s like other Justices do if they are in the shape to do so. He appreciates the work of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., who served on the court for 32 years. Breyer is approaching 27 years on the court, with lots of energy left, it seems.
This was a time update forecast.

Increasing the odds of 1 due to the political calendar. A Breyer retirement seems most likely while the Court isn't in session. Given the 2022 election cycle and the razor thin Senate majority for confirmation, I'm increasing the odds of it coming this summer.
Article today has announced all nine have been "completely vaccinated" which I assume means both doses. Slightly increase my faith in 0.

An interesting analysis from one of the best named blogs around.[1]  I had not considered this point: it is not uncommon for the composition of the Senate to change in between elections due to deaths.  With so many elderly Dems, seven according to this article, the blogger is making the point that Breyer does need to act quickly if he does not wish to have another RBG situation.   Supreme Court Justices apparently do not begin reviewing applications for their clerks for the coming year on a set schedule, according to my cursory research, which would be a good indicator. [1] https://www.lawyersgunsmoneyblog.com/2021/03/why-hasnt-stephen-breyer-retired-yet

If it happens (most likely Breyer passing the torch) I would expect it to be this summer, because the SCOTUS will be in recess: https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/2020TermCourtCalendar.pdf Democrats are well aware that the window of opportunity of holding the Senate is temporary and could very well be closed in 2023. Next year is an election year, so it would not be wise to wait until then. If Breyer's resignation does not happen this summer, the SCOTUS goes back into session in October, so it should be low single digits at that point: https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/2021TermCourtCalendar.pdf
Change: 0+15 Reasoning: I'm betting Bryer is going to wait until 2022.
1 up 10% to be ahead of the consensus.

Slight adjustment to the "2" bucket in light of Manchin's stated opposition to Biden's OMB pick [1 and 2]. Manchin's willingness to use his "power of 1" in this way does seem to reflect on the likelihood of Dems "packing the SC" in 2021, especially given his already stated position on the subject [2 and 3, noting that 3's statements were made during the highly sensitive  Georgia run offs]. Where do thoughts of retirement come from?
falling in with the crowd. Breyer is obvious, 80% likely in my view, but WHEN is not....
(no change) I'm sure the supremes are reflecting on the problems Congress is having. Might be just enough to nudge someone.

Although Justice Breyer has pressure in some quarters to retire this year, he has commented on the record that he will "retire eventually." Had his retirement been discussed and seriously contemplated over the course of this year, one would think that he would have commented differently.  Sources: https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/06/liberals-to-breyer-retire-455321

Holy cow this is hard to base rate. I'm gonna say that we have to look at age and health (to gauge likelihood of a justice passing away) and age & time-served (to gauge likelihood of retirement). According to this article from 2018, recent judges retire at around age 80 and after 27 years on the court (https://www.businessinsider.com/supreme-court-when-ginsberg-other-justices-could-quit-based-on-age-tenure-2018-6#:~:text=The%20average%20age%20of%20retirement,shorter%2C%20at%2016%20years). Clarence Thomas is well past the average time served, but pretty young still. Breyer is older than the average age of retirement and hits the average length of service this year. There's a bit of pressure for him to retire (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-court/u-s-supreme-courts-breyer-in-retirement-spotlight-after-democratic-wins-idUSKBN29C2S5), but not a ton. Given Thomas's ideological position, it's tough to see him stepping down soon, though admittedly the court is fairly conservative now, so he might feel "safer" doing so.
Breyer is the most likely person to retire, or die, in order to make space for a new judge. Rumours suggests that Breyer may retire to allow new selection, but has not been confirmed.
Possibility Breyer retires whilst there is a Democrat majority in the senate and a democrat president. However there would be no reason to retire in 2021 vs 2022

For the most recent 30 years of its history, the Supreme Court has averaged a vacancy every 3.3 years.  To make a good prediction for the current court, politics must be considered.  So here we go: 
-Only 1 justice (Breyer) is "old" by SCOTUS standards.  Having been a Clinton appointee, he could theoretically retire during the Biden administration without altering the balance.  I see no reason that he would retire from the court prior to the end of the year.  
-Sotomayor (Obama), Kagan (Obama), Gorsuch (Trump), Kavanaugh (Trump), Coney Barrett (Trump), and Roberts (Bush) are all considered young by SCOTUS standards.
-Alito (Bush), Thomas (Bush the elder), both traditionalists have no incentive to leave the court during the Biden administration.  
-Finally, adding justices to the court...what is being called "court packing" in the media, will not happen this year.  Although the majority of democrats would love to balance the Supreme Court, in the end it will be a political decision (not to mention that it would set a bad precedent... one co-equal branch of government altering another with very shaky Constitutional authority?).  Some may disagree on this point...but the bottom line is that it will not happen in year one unless legislative and executive priorities change drastically.

Slight adjustment on probabilities for 2021: 1.  Downwards for "3 or more" given the Democrats seem far more comfortable using reconciliation to cut through the filibuster than engage in anything more seismic (which reflects on their willingness to kill off the filibuster entirely, which in turn would be an enabler and a potential precursor to expanding the supreme court). https://www.cbsnews.com/news/covid-relief-democrats-1-9-trillion-plan/
https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/01/democrats-stimulus-coronavirus-reconciliation-464533 Seems likely Dems will only start aggressively exploring SC expansion as a responsive act to Republicans over-playing their hand and trying to (succeeding in?) legally challenging keystone Dem policies through the conservative tilted SC. Such a scenario would take time and be very "out in the open": very unlikely in the backdrop of 2021's priorities and turbulence.  Given its popularity and the Republicans focus on regaining some form of legislative control in 2022, the COVID relief package would seem a very unwise hand for Republicans to play their SC "Trump" card in (forgive the unavoidable pun). That said, the Rep Party and its "strategy" is all over the place right now (being reactively jerked all over the field by Trump subservience, the Tea Party, Citizens United, moderates & fiscal conservatives etc.) so bad plays and ideologically driven missteps are entirely possible. 2.  A raise for "1" given that Dems seem keen to make the most of their wholesale control of all three branches while they have it. With 2022 shaping up to be the next big political fight for legislative control, and with redistricting and gerrymandering at state level [1 & 2] making a return to Republican Senate (and potentially House) control a viable possibility, the likelihood of Breyer being encouraged to retire in 2021 (to take this off the table as a conservative animating voting issue in 2022) feels somewhat more likely. [1]  https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/31/us/politics/gerrymander-census-democrats-republicans.html
[2]  https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2020/11/democrats-statehouses-republican-control-gerrymandering-redistricting-census.html A potential anti-gerrymandering bill being pushed through the legislature later (but not much later) in 2021 to counter Republicans significant redistricting advantage for the 2022 election season seems likely.  Equally: a Republican led, state level legal challenge to this bill (founded on a claim of federal government overreach) making its way to the conservative heavy SC seems equally likely. This scenario also seems to increase the likelihood of a Breyer retirement, with Dems wanting to shore up as much of their SC control as possible to give this critical political bill the best chance in the SC.  It also seems fair to say that Dems will have learnt a painful lesson from the sudden and tragic demise of RBG at the worst possible moment and would wish to leave less to chance in the future. Lots of reasons why a graceful 2021 departure for Breyer is a sound political and strategic move for Democrats.  It all seems to hang on whether or not he wants to go along with it. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Breyer 3.  "2" remains in place at 10% given the higher possibility in 2021 of illness or death afflicting at least one member of the ageing SC in addition to the above rationale for "1 or more".

In the recent political environment, partisan considerations are fairly 'forward' in decisions that might be made here, barring health issues in middle-aged and elderly justices.  The overall age of all the justices certainly puts the chance of every seat becoming vacant above zero.   Justice Breyer is the oldest member of the court who might be inclined to step down for ideological reasons during the Biden administration/democratic Senate majority.  However, no Justice has publically indicated that they are moving in the direction of retirement.  Justices who may be privately considering it may feel that they have several years of the Biden presidency to make an ideologically motivated decision.   Justices also serve for life and are likely to have personal and institutional pressures towards continuing to serve while able, often (in recent history) to great age. Another part of the question presented includes the possibility democratic government leaders will expand the Supreme Court.  Political challenges and opportunity costs make this a very costly attempt that the democrats are unlikely to gain consensus to try.

I find it likely that Breyer will choose to retire in 2021, rather than in 2022.  Political scientists find good evidence that so-called "strategic retirements" from the Court are a real thing.[1]   The Republicans cannot filibuster a SCOTUS nominee, but I would guess that Breyer does not want his legacy to be remembered as having paved the way for an even further conservative stranglehold on the court if he waits until 2022 to retire.  If he waits into 2022, his vacancy will become the center of political controversy and a focus of the mid-term senate races.  The president's party generally does poorly in the mid-terms.  If the Democrats lose their slimmest of majorities then Mitch McConnell would return to being the majority leader, jeopardizing much of what Breyer would hope to see in the direction of the Court in the future.  He must be mindful of how disastrously Ruth Bader Ginsburg's decision not to retire turned out to be for those who view the Constitution in the way they do.  By retiring in 2021, he would short circuit all of the preceding.   That said, I leave a healthy probability that he will do just the opposite since people are "incomprehensible," to quote Sidney Pollack in the movie, "Michael Clayton." [1] https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00993415

I believe it is unlikely there will be another death of a Supreme Court Judge this year. Accordingly, now that the Democratic Party controls the White House, The House of Representatives, and the Senate, the likelihood is that the Democratic Party would seek to amend the Constitution is low. I just don't see why the Democratic Party would risk a backlash at the next (2022) election. That said, if a change is made, it is more likely to be two vacancies established in order to keep the number of Supreme Court Judges as an odd number.

This one is very interesting and involves lots of layers. Let start with the big picture. The average justice since 1900 serves an average of 26 years on the bench. The average of justices who choose to retire is about 74 years old. Five of the last eight President's had a vacancy in their first year in office. This includes the last two Democratic Presidents who were boosted by a retirement during their first year (1993 and 2009). The overall rate of a vaccancy is one about ever 2.06 years. Based on this, there are two Justices who are likely on retirement watch, Justice Thomas and Justice Breyer. Justice Thomas is extremely unlikely to retire. An opening of his seat would likely be due to health issues although that does not appear to be an immediate concern.  Justice Breyer however will be under extreme pressure to retire during the next two years. Although the Senate map is favorable in 2022, Liberal democrats will likely not want to take the risk and will apply pressure on Breyer during the next 12 months. Will he be receptive? I think he will be more than perhaps a year ago given the RGB seat and the general politics of the day. It could be interesting to wathc his votes and opinions during the Spring term for any hints of his thinking.  That is only half the story. There is also the push from the left on court packing, or adding seats. President Biden has not ruled it out but has generally not been overly supportive of the idea. His compromise was a commission to study court reform that could be announced in the coming days. They have a six month timeline to produce a final report so a decision on court-packing might not come this year. The commission is also being headed by someone who in 2018 shot down the idea of court-packing. The recommendation is more likely to focus on term-limits, ethics code, and bringing the court into the 21st century. Bottom line, in 2021 Senate Democrats and the President will likely focus more on lower court openings and being ready if Breyer does announce his retirement.

I figure the real death chance is rather lower than the SSA actuarial tables (better health care and living conditions than average, 1/12th the year already passed), while the chance Breyer will resign to arrange his replacement between Supreme Court terms while the Democrats have a Senate majority then pushes up the odds a little (but he's likely thinking "next year" on that, even though it ups the risk of a Senate D being replaced by an R). Vacancies created by expanding the Court simply aren't going to happen. Even if Biden's commission came back for it (unlikely, given the composition), and there was a majority for it in the Senate (there isn't), it would require eliminating the filibuster first (and there are currently 52 votes against that in the Senate). This is especially true given that the Biden Administration just demonstrated they have absolutely no idea how to actually try to get Senatorial support for a bill (the Vice President going to Arizona and West Virginia to try to pressure Manchin and Sinema by talking to local media indicates some absolute idiots are making the decisions).

There are three ways for a vacancy to arise, either a) a supreme court justice passes away or b) a supreme court justice resigns or c) the court is expanded in size.  The probability of a given justice passing away in the year 2021 are given by the US actuarial life table [1] combine with the supreme court justice's ages and genders [2]:  Clarence Thomas (72) - 2.7%
Stephen Breyer (82) - 7.1%
John G. Roberts (66) - 1.7%
Samuel A. Alito, Jr (70) - 2.2% 
Sonia Sotomayor (66) - 1.1%
Elena Kagan (60) - 0.6% 
Neil McGill Gorsuch (53) - 0.6% 
Brett Michael Kavanaugh (55) - 0.7%
Amy Coney Barrett (48) - 0.2%  Thus, the probability of no justices dying is: (100-2.7)/100 * (100-7.1)/100 * (100-1.7)/100 * (100- 2.2)/100 * (100- 1.1) /100* (100- 0.6) /100* (100-0.6)/100 * (100-0.7)/100 * (100-0.2)/100 = 84%. 
The probability of one justice dying is: 12%
The probability of two justices dying is: 3% 
The probability of three or more justices dying is: < 1% 

The probability of a justice resigning is more subjective. It seems highly improbable any conservative justice would resign (as their spot would be filled by Biden). Thus, the justices to focus on resigning are Breyer, Sotomayor, and Kagan. Since Sotomayor and Kagan are both likely to serve for at least 10+ years, there is no reason for them to resign. Breyer is 82 and probably will resign before the end of Biden's presidency. However, I would think it unlikely that this would occur during this first year of Biden's presidency. Biden will likely have control of the senate until midterm elections, and so I think it is likely Breyer will resign before the midterms to ensure Democrats still control the Senate, but probably not this year. I'll give this a 5% chance of occurring this year.  The probability that the court is expanded is also subjective. I think it is highly unlikely that this occurs.  Hence, my predictions are: 
79% - 0 
16% - 1
4% - 2

I think it is more likely than not there will be no vacancies in 2021. The Court is relatively young and appear to be in good health. At 82, Justice Breyer is the oldest of the nine Justices, and though there may be some pressure for him to retire and allow his spot to be filled by someone younger with similar political leanings, he may not be in a hurry to step down. The Court has undergone significant change over the past few years, and Breyer may want to remain on the Court to lend it stability. If he delayed his retirement until 2022, his seat could still be filled by the Biden administration. There is a chance he will retire in 2021, but I think it is more likely he'll try to wait. Of course, Justice Breyer's retirement is not the only event that could result in a vacancy. With a more contagious strain of Covid-19 spreading, there is a chance that one or more of the Justices could vacate a seat due to serious illness or death. Justice Breyer is not the only Justice who would be considered at-risk for a poor Covid-19 outcome. Although the Justices would have the resources to receive top medical treatment, the virus is somewhat unpredictable and there is a chance one of the nine could become infected and have unexpected complications from the virus. I think it is very unlikely we will see any sort reform or restructuring of the Court that would result in multiple vacancies.

Based on the ages of current justices, probability of death based on mortality tables are mostly <1%. I suspect the math will tell me there is a roughly 5% probability of death or any member. Multiple deaths further reduces the probability.  Retirement is an important question. The tenure of the court is low and a conservative justice is unlikely to step down in this environment.  Of the liberal justices, Breyer is the biggest risk. He’s the oldest and there have already been calls for his retirement so the Biden administration can nominate someone. This study (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3000028/#!po=0.531915) shows an increased probability of an increase in odds of departure if the current president is the same as the one that nominated that justice. While this is a compelling argument, I could see Breyer waiting a year to let the administration push other priorities in 2021.

The age of the justices are all relatively young, so health issues causing a justice to die in 2021 are negligible.  The only real candidate for health problems or retirement would be Stephen Breyer.  As the oldest member of the court at age 82, health could become a factor.  The most likely scenario, however, would be his retirement resulting from political pressure on the left.  There is a desire for him to retire while Democrats control both the White House and Senate to ensure his seat remains liberal for decades to come.  If this is to happen, it is highly likely it would be in 2021 to avoid campaign issues in 2022.  However, Breyer has not given any indication that his retirement is imminent.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-court/u-s-supreme-courts-breyer-in-retirement-spotlight-after-democratic-wins-idUSKBN29C2S5 The likelihood of two or more seats coming vacant would likely be a result of Democrats seeking to pack the court. While there was much discussion on this potential during the 2020 Presidential Election, there is no consensus among Democrats that this would be a desirable tactic, so I place the odds of this happening at 0%.

There is not much chance of the six conservatives retiring during a Democratic presidency.  They also appear healthy so I do not feel a need to consult the Social Security survivorship tables.  I believe the chances of one of the conservatives dying is also pretty low.  Among the liberals, Justices Sotomayor and Kagan could retire during a Democratic presidency but Supreme Court justices typically serve until their 80s and both are in their 60s.  Thus, I doubt either one will retire.  Both seem healthy.  I doubt either one will die in the next year.   Justice Breyer has said he will retire at some point per Fox News article below.  He will not go out like RBG--working literally until the day she died.   This year is Justice Breyer's best to leave and get a successor he likes.  If he stays, until the end of the Biden presidency, he will be 84-years-old and who knows what will follow: Another Trump?  He would be 88-years-old at the end of that term, and he did say he wanted to retire.    Biden would likely appoint someone likeminded to both Breyer and Biden, and there are 50 Democratic votes to approve.  The democrats will need one Republican since 51 votes (not including the VP) are needed to break a filibuster.   I think they can negotiate with either Mitt Romney, Susan Collins or Lisa Murkowski to find an acceptable nominee to get past this.   Justice Breyer worked for the senate judiciary committee under Senator Edward Kennedy before becoming a judge so he understands the politics of a nomination better than most.   To that end, there is no guarantee that Democrats will still control the senate after the 2022 election, and Republicans might hold the position open until 2024 if Breyer retired in 2023 or 2024.  Remember Merritt Garland!   Also, just today,  Vermont Senator Leahy had to leave the senate by ambulance due to illness.  Vermont has a Republican Governor, and Leahy and a number of other Democratic senators are in their 80s.  Thus, Democrats could lose the senate literally at any moment.   Breyer almost certainly wants to retire in sufficient time for a thorough vetting process to be completed and to give the president a second nomination opportunity, if needed.    Most justices retire near the end of the term unless there is a medical issue.  The current term ends and the new term begins the first Monday in October.   I suspect Breyer will announce his retirement sometime after the impeachment trial so as not to be a distraction.  I also thought he might announce prior to the period for applications for law clerks began to let any potential clerk know not to apply.  Unfortunately, I could not find a day by which prospective law clerks to the Supreme Court have to turn in their applications, but I did find some for the lower courts, including the Ninth and D.C. Circuits.  The dates vary from end of February to mid-June.     I also briefly looked at the dates some other more recent justices announced their retirements.  Mid-April for Justice Kennedy was the earliest and September for Justice Stewart was the latest, except in cases of illness, e.g., Marshall. Thus, I am back where I started:  what would be a sufficient amount of time to allow a new justice to start in October and the president sufficient time to complete the process--which should be extremely contentious in the current climate?    I think five to eight months before October would likely be the time frame.  However, eight months would conflict with impeachment, which will likely end in  February or March, Therefore, I think  we will know between the end of February and end of May  if he is leaving this year.  After that, my forecast will be near 100 percent  for zero.   https://www.foxnews.com/politics/supreme-court-justice-stephen-breyer-retire-eventually

I think the initial 83% for 0 is a little overstated. There are a lot of calls for 82 year-old Stephen Breyer to retire while Democrats hold the Senate. If he waits until next year, then it becomes an election year issue, when it'll be an off-year election and the last thing Democrats will want is a motivated GOP base.

Current ages are 72, 82, 66, 70, 66, 60, 53, 55, and 49. Depending on how you skin the cat, average age of retirement is 73. Breyer is oldest at 82, has mentioned retirement, and was a democratic selection (favorable replacement with democrat controlled presidency and Senate)
Helpful source:  Epstein, Lee, Thomas G. Walker, Nancy Staudt, Scott Hendrickson, and Jason Roberts. (2021). "The U.S. Supreme Court Justices Database." January 17. At: http://epstein.wustl.edu/research/justicesdata.html.

Justice Breyer is the most likely to step down, but it is more likely he would do so in the second year of the Biden administration. I doubt that the number of Supreme Court seats will be increased given there will certainly be opposition from Republicans and moderate Democrats. The outlier is the unexpected death of a justice but none currently seem to have serious health problems.

Justice Breyer is statistically the most likely vacancy. Would he consider vacating his seat to ensure President Biden can nominate before the mid-terms? My guess is not this year, unless he were to become ill. I cannot see any of the Republican appointees vacating, and Justices Kagan and Sotomayor are still relatively young.
The obvious outlier is whether President Biden's commission recommends increasing the number of justices. Whilst court packing is popular some circles, it seems slightly counterproductive - the 'other side' can simply do the same and the court quickly gets too big. To get the 'balance' desired 4 new justices would be required (leading to 13 - perhaps someone superstitious might not like that!).
For now I am suggesting this is unlikely. However, as the commission gets going, I am sure more information will leak and we can reassess.

Initial forecast. Usual reasons, subject to details of how the US Senate is operating (or not) and if there are any party changes. FWIW the commission on judges/courts has a 180 (edited) day target, but they will only be recommendations. Unless there is a wave of bipartisanship, any good ideas might gather a bit of dust.
